    Model typical behaviour and Estimate Lower Extreme Threshold

    model_extremes.Rd

    Fits an ARIMA model on a subset of the time series representing "typical" behavior and estimates a lower extreme threshold based on either Extreme Value Theory (EVT) using the Generalized Pareto Distribution (GPD) or a boxplot-based approach.

    model_extremes(
  typical_data = NULL,
  full_data = NULL,
  time_col,
  typical_start = NULL,
  typical_end = NULL,
  response,
  thr_prob_fit = 0.05,
  thr_prob_alarm = 0.005,
  t_method = c("evd", "boxplot"),
  k = 1
)

    Arguments

    typical_data

    A tsibble containing the typical observation window for model fitting. If provided, this dataset will be used instead of subsetting `full_data`.

    full_data

    Optional tsibble object containing both typical observation window and test data window. (ignored if `typical_data` is provided).

    time_col

    Name of the time index column.

    typical_start

    Optional Start date-time (character or POSIXct) defining the beginning of the typical observation window used for model fitting. (ignored if `typical_data` is provided).

    typical_end

    End date-time (character or POSIXct) defining the end of the typical observation window. (ignored if `typical_data` is provided).

    response

    The response variable to model, passed as an unquoted column name.

    thr_prob_fit

    Numeric. Tail probability used to define the POT threshold for fitting the Generalized Pareto Distribution (GPD). A larger value (e.g. 0.05) includes more tail observations to improve parameter stability.

    thr_prob_alarm

    Numeric. Tail probability used when computing the lower extreme limit from the fitted GPD. This is typically smaller than thr_prob_fit (e.g. 0.005) to obtain a more conservative alarm threshold and reduce false positives.

    t_method

    Character string indicating the threshold estimation method. Options are:

    • `"evd"` — estimates the threshold using the Generalized Pareto Distribution.

    • `"boxplot"` — uses the boxplot rule (1.5 × IQR below Q1) to identify lower extremes.

    k

    Numeric. Safety margin multiplier applied to the EVT-derived lower limit. This value widens the threshold to reduce false positives by accounting for estimation uncertainty in the tail. For example, k = 0.5 subtracts half a standard deviation of residuals from the EVT lower limit.

    Value

    A list containing:

    model

    The fitted ARIMA model object.

    lower_limit

    The estimated lower extreme threshold.

    threshold_method

    The threshold estimation method used (`"evd"` or `"boxplot"`).

    typical_data

    The subset of the time series used for model fitting.

    response

    The response variable name.

    time_col

    Name of the time index column.

    Details

    The function first subsets the input time series between `typical_start` and `typical_end` to capture non-extreme, representative behavior. An ARIMA model is automatically fitted using the `fable` framework, and residuals are extracted.

    Depending on the chosen `t_method`, the lower extreme threshold is estimated:

    • For `"evd"` — the Generalized Pareto Distribution is fitted to the lower tail of residuals using fpot() from the evd package.

    • For `"boxplot"` — the lower whisker (Q1 − 1.5 × IQR) is used as the threshold.

    Examples

    # Create a sample daily time series dataset (use Date, not POSIXct)
data <- tsibble::tsibble(
  date = seq.Date(as.Date("2020-01-01"), as.Date("2020-12-31"), by = "day"),
  value = c(rnorm(300),rnorm(66, -3)),
  index = date
)

# Run the model_extremes function
result <- model_extremes(
  full_data = data,
  time_col = date,
  typical_start = "2020-01-01",
  typical_end = "2020-08-30",
  response = value,
  thr_prob_fit = 0.1,
  t_method = "boxplot"
)
#> # A tsibble: 243 x 2 [1D]
#>    date          value
#>    <date>        <dbl>
#>  1 2020-01-01 -1.40   
#>  2 2020-01-02  0.255  
#>  3 2020-01-03 -2.44   
#>  4 2020-01-04 -0.00557
#>  5 2020-01-05  0.622  
#>  6 2020-01-06  1.15   
#>  7 2020-01-07 -1.82   
#>  8 2020-01-08 -0.247  
#>  9 2020-01-09 -0.244  
#> 10 2020-01-10 -0.283  
#> # ℹ 233 more rows
